Posts.Content: Until you get the results of a biopsy there’s no way to tell if you’ve had spread or not unless organs start shutting down. If the biopsy says cancer they will also be genomic testing to determine how aggressive it is. There will also likely be a PET scan and a bone scan to to for cancerous lesions once they have a positive biopsy. Please let us know the biopsy results.
Posts.Title: Just told I have breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Cancer spreads 3 ways: 1-growing into an adjacent organ 2-spreading through lymph system 3-spread through vascular (blood) system The first two are easily tested, the third is the reason they use adjuvant chemotherapy. If this turns out to be cancer they will do genomic testing to learn what they can about the cancer. They will be looking to test the grade of the cancer and to learn if it is fed by 3 different hormones: estrogen, progesterone and HER2. The information they get from this testing will tell them how aggressive the cancer is. It will also give them an idea of how often cells like yours (IF it’s cancer) metastasize and which chemotherapy drugs it will or will not respond to. It also informs long term maintenance and follow up. They will know if you can benefit from a treatment like tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor. At this point there are more questions than answers. Take a friend or family member with you to take. notes. Get copies of your reports and put them in an accordion file to organize them. Another excellent resource you will find helpful is breast cancer.org
Posts.Title: Just told I have breast cancer.

Posts.Content: If you’ve had 1 Cancer you’re at an increased risk for a second or even third cancer. Your doctor may be making a choice to err on the side of caution.
Posts.Title: Over testing survivors???

Posts.Content: Welcome. How can we help you?
Posts.Title: Advocates

Posts.Content: It’s good that you are staying on top of your mammograms. There are other causes of calcification but you doctor is being cautious. Is your doctor a breast care specialist? How many breast biopsies has the surgeon performed? Was an ultrasound done? If neither doctor specializes in breast care get a second opinion with a specialist.
Posts.Title: Biopsy

Posts.Content: That’s the one my oncologist used and breastcancer.org does say it has the most research behind it. Breastcancer.org has been an excellent resource for me.
Posts.Title: DCIS - Treatment Decisions

Posts.Content: If they do a biopsy they will have done oncotype testing. This is how they came to the Intermediate Grade diagnosis. Ask for a copy of the report.
Posts.Title: DCIS - Treatment Decisions

Posts.Content: More than likely it’s the Chemo and radiation to blame. I was diagnosed with stage 1 breast cancer but had chemo and radiation for lung cancer 8 years ago. I still experience fatigue. Exercise helped me regain some Of my strength and stamina but I tire easily. I get better and stronger every year. If you think that you might be able experiencing excessive fatigue talk to your doctor about Ritalin. Patients like us are the reason why Ritalin was developed.
Posts.Title: Still Tired Three Years After Breast Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: You’ve identified your trigger. Now just don’t check in and read. Just stay away from threads and sites you know will depress you
Posts.Title: Talking About it/Doesn't make it any Better!

Posts.Content: I’m not on Arimidex but a quick check of the health library indicates that insomnia is a known side effect. https://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/drugInfo.cfm?setid=acbfaaa...
Posts.Title: Hope living with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Karen. Getting started on exercise, even for a couch potato like me, is never easy. Commit 5 minutes a day to walking through/around your home/halls. It will help generate energy during the day and contribute to sleeping at night. The B12 everyone recommended was a good plan too.
Posts.Title: Still Tired Three Years After Breast Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: No one should have to face this alone. Contact the oncology social worker at your hospital and ask about patient support groups. Also reach out to your local American Cancer Society and inquire about the look good feel better program. The radiation you had used X-rays. It's possible to have proton radiation to a spot that has already had traditional radiation. If your hospital doesn’t offer it they may not suggest it. I’ve asked three different radiologists if that would be possible as I’ve had radiation for lung and breast cancers. I wanted to know if I can use it when I experience progression. Things look their bleakest when going through treatment because we get so fatigued. As you recover you might look into rescuing an older dog or cat from a shelter. An animal that’s 2-3 years or older likely has been housebroken. Our pets have meant so much to my recovery.
Posts.Title: Hope living with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I have not experienced lymphodema but as a survivor of two cancers I have made an observation which may help. Our doctors/oncologists/radiologists know a great deal about the treatment they are administering but do not have a good understanding of the issues surrounding side effects, especially long term side effects. In a case like this I would follow the recommendations of the lymphedema specialist. This is what they deal with, the only thing they deal with, and their knowledge base about it is far more extensive. Also this was reinforced in an Ask the Specialist session at a recent educational seminar. The upshot was as they had no clue about long term side effect management and the need for physical therapy and other interventions. I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: How do I handle my lymphedema during radiation treatment?
